Award.AwardTitle: A Multi-Wavelength Observing Program of Io Using Adaptive Optics and Interferometric Techniques
Award.AbstractNarration: Io is one of the most remarkable bodies in our solar system, with volcanoes driven by tidal heating and complex interactions with Jupiter's magnetosphere. Despite extensive studies from the ground and from spacecraft, fundamental questions, concerning the nature and location of internal dissipation, the composition of the dominant magma, and the interactions among the volcanoes, surface frost, atmosphere, and Jupiter's magnetic field, remain unanswered. The proposing team will conduct an extensive observational program of imaging and spectroscopy to monitor Io's volcanoes and atmosphere, making use of a wide range of telescope facilities including the Atacama Large Millimeter/Submillimeter Array (ALMA), the Combined Array for Research in Millimeter-Wave Astronomy (CARMA), the Infrared Telescope Facility (IRTF), and the Gemini and Keck Observatories. These observations will yield (1) global maps of Io at 1-5 microns, at least once a year, to map and monitor volcanic activity; (2) determinations of the sulfur monoxide gas distribution while Io is in Jupiter's shadow; (3) observations of sulfur monoxide and sulfur dioxide gases to constrain the structure of and dynamics in Io's atmosphere; and (4) correlations of atmospheric sulfur monoxide and sulfur dioxide gases with sulfur dioxide ice and volcanic hot spots. The global infrared maps of Io, will be integrated into the USGS global Io database. The project will support the work of undergraduate and graduate students, and proposing team members will be involved in a variety of public outreach activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Io is a most fascinating satellite: it is the most volcanically active body in our Solar System, and it is the only body with a SO2-dominated atmosphere. However, despite several spacecraft encounters and ground-based monitoring for ∼50 years, we still lack a basic understanding of Io's volcanic activity. 

In this NSF proposal we investigated the relationships among Io's volcanic activity, its heat flow and its atmosphere through a multi-wavelength observing program. Particularly, we observed Io at infrared wavelengths with the Gemini and Keck telescopes to document the spatial distribution, temperature of the erupting magmas, and frequency of eruptions. We mapped the spatial distribution of SO and SO2 gas using the Atacama Large Millimeter/submillimeter Array (ALMA) at 1-2 mm when Io went into eclipse (Jupiter's shadow) and emerged from eclipse. The SO spatial distribution was also mapped at 1.707 mm with the Keck telescope. 

Several graduate and many undergraduate students participated in the project.

Our findings are summarized within a broader context of Io in Annu. Rev. Earth Planet. Sci. 2021, 49:1?30 (https://doi.org/10.1146/annurev-earth-082420-095244). Results are also summarized on de Pater?s website under : http://w.astro.berkeley.edu/~imke/Infrared/Io/IoGeneral.htm, and http://w.astro.berkeley.edu/~imke/RadioPage/Io_ALMA/Io_alma.htm.

 

Global maps and the spatial distribution of hot spots (see Fig. 1).

Hot spots are seen globally, but appear to be most frequent at mid-latitudes and in two regions shifted eastward from the sub/anti-Jupiter points by ~300, with a relative lack right at equatorial latitudes. While the number of hotspots and cumulative near-IR radiance is nearly identical between the leading and trailing hemispheres, bright transient eruptions usually take place on the trailing hemisphere, and at preferentially higher latitudes.  A comparison to tidal heating models show a good correspondence between recent models incorporating a partially fluid interior and hot spots in the leading hemisphere as well as persistent hot spots. However, hot spots on the trailing hemisphere and bright eruptions do not match these models well, corresponding better to standard deep-mantle heating models, although this match is still imperfect. 

During our observing campaigns we detected many large and several "outburst" eruptions. Such eruptions provide a wealth of information on the style of eruptions, and the derived temperature may constrain the composition of the lava.

 

Loki Patera 

Of all of Io's hundreds of volcanoes, none is more enigmatic than Loki Patera, a dark, horseshoe-shaped feature that is the most powerful persistently active volcano on Io. We extended the timeline up through 2016, and modeled the eruptions with an overturning lava lake. A unique observation was obtained on March 2015, with the Large Binocular Telescope Interferometer (LBTI)  when Europa passed in front of Io, gradually blocking out light from Io. Europa took about 10 seconds to completely cover Loki Patera, with a time resolution of ~2 km across Io's surface. This allowed us to construct detailed temperature and lava cooling age maps of Loki Patera. We showed that Loki Patera is resurfaced by two waves that propagate and converge around the central island. The resurfacing is multi-phase, and the different velocities and start times of the waves indicate a non-uniformity in the lava gas content and/or crust bulk density across the patera. This paper represents a flagstone on our Loki Patera work, but begs for more observations during the next mutual satellite eclipse era.

 

Observations of Io's atmosphere

One outstanding question for Io's atmosphere is whether it is driven primarily by sublimation of SO2 frost from it surface, or by volcanic activity. Observations of Io right before, after, and during an eclipse provide the best way to separate the volcanic from sublimation-driven contributions. The atmospheric temperature is expected to drop within minutes after Io enters an eclipse. The SO2 gas that makes up the bulk of Io's atmosphere is expected to condense out on a similar timescale, unless a layer of noncondensible gases prevents rapid collapse. 

We used the Keck telescope to observe the spatial distribution of SO (1.707 mm) while Io was in eclipse. The SO spatial distribution showed that the emissions were largely uncorrelated with known volcanic sites. We suggested the emissions to be caused by widespread stealth volcanism, i.e., volcanic plumes that lack dust and condensates, and therefore have not been seen before by spacecraft in reflected sunlight. 

We used ALMA in the 1-2 mm bands when the satellite moved into and out from an eclipse. During eclipse ingress, the SO2 flux density dropped exponentially, and the atmosphere re-formed in a linear fashion when re-emerging in sunlight. While both the in-eclipse decrease and in-sunlight increase in SO was more gradual than for SO2, the fact that SO decreased at all is evidence that SO in a sense condensed as well (i.e., self-reactions at the surface are important and fast,), and that in-sunlight photolysis of SO2 is the dominant source of SO. There also was clear evidence of volcanic plumes of SO2 and SO gases.
